history.content: This sounds very reasonable workload. 161 is moderate workload and 188 is easy enough. For humanity, choose whatever you are interested in and pass no pass it so you won't have much workload in it

children.subject:
It's totally manageable, and you can use the humanities class to sharpen your academic paper writing skills too.

Most Humanity classes at Berkeley have a lot of reading (which professors will encourage you to skim through as opposed to fully read in depth), at least 1 8+ page paper and fairly easy tests, given you've gone to the classes. To some it sounds like a lot, but if you have an interest in the subject, the reading and paper will be a breeze (most papers are designed to be super open ended, and 9/10 times, your GSI will be happy to read over it before you turn it in).

My advice is to find a niche subject you think is cool, send an email to the professor asking about what to expect, and then just go to class.

Just a follow-up on the humanities class: Linguistics 100 is a really awesome intro course and was easy to get an A by just showing up and reading the textbook. Also, the workload was low and the material was interesting. Would highly recommend.

history.content: Any advice? Hello, I am visiting Berkeley in the upcoming semester. I was just wondering if the workload above sounds doable(why or why not). I know the classes are hard but I kind of need to have a mininum of 4 classes to satisfy requirements at my home school. Lastly, I will definitedly appreciate if anyone can recommend a very easy and low workload humanities course that I can take.
history.subject: 170 + 161 + 188  + 1 humanities/social science course
